Description: Sherd (base with wall fragment). Pottery (earthenware), with a honey coloured glaze. Shield medallion of polo sticks. Chukandar (polo master) symbol and nisba on wall. Sgraffito, partly coloured with chocolate-brown slip.
Curator's comments: Polo originated in pre-Islamic Iran and gradually spread westward to the Arab lands, reaching its height in popularity amongst the elites of the Ayyubid and Mamluk dynasties of Egypt and the Levant. This sherd comes from vessels belonging to a chukandar, an official responsible for the care of the polo sticks (chawgan) and for the conduct of the game. The chukandar’s coat of arms features two curved and addorsed chawgans.
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2012 - 2013 7 Aug - 27 Jan, BM, 'Fair Play: Heroes, Athletes & Princes in Islamic Art'
